title: First pictures of married couple held over frozen bodies found in Essex lorry
text:
Police swooped on the Cheshire home of Joanna and Thomas Maher, 38 (Picture: PA)

A husband and wife named as the last known owners of a lorry containing the bodies of 39 migrants have been pictured.

Joanna Maher and haulage firm boss Thomas Maher, both 38, were arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people and manslaughter earlier today.

Police raided their £400,000 home in Warrington, Cheshire and their beauty salon around the corner, named New Hair Don’t Care.

The pair, who remain in custody, said they sold the cab in October 2018 and had voluntarily gone to the police themselves.

Officers photographed the Irish couple’s £40,000 Range Rover Discovery, £50,000 Range Rover Sport and white Cevrolet Corvette, all with personalised number plates, on their driveway this morning.

The pair are being held in custody of 39 counts of manslaughter and people trafficking charges

Officers were seen photographing the couple’s cars on their driveway in Warrington (Picture: Peter Powell)

The couple say they sold the cab more than a year ago (Picture: Peter Powell)

A neighbour, who saw police arrive at the home said: ‘I am shell-shocked. I know the family well. Tom really loves his cars.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

The Scania truck was registered in 2018 at the Black Sea port of Varna, Bulgaria – an area used as a cigarette and fuel smuggling route by Irish republican gangs.

Ivan Jeliazkov, who handled the sale of the cab, today said the couple were ‘100 per cent innocent’, MailOnline reports.

He added: ‘They are not criminals. I have known them for several years and know they have three children who love them very much. They are good people.’

The -25C refrigerated trailer, in which the victims are believed to have frozen to death, is thought to be owned by Dublin based rental firm GTR tailers, but registered in Northern Ireland.

A Gardai source told the Irish Daily Mail there is ‘nothing to suggest’ the firms knew of the people kept inside the container.

The Bulgarian businessman who handled the cab’s sale to them said they were ‘100 per cent innocent’

Their arrests followed that of 25-year-old driver Mo Robinson on Wednesday (Picture: Peter Powell)

Although Essex Police initially said all occupants were Chinese nationals, the BBC has been in contact with six Vietnamese families who fear their loved ones are among the dead.

The relatives of Pham Thi Tra, 26, said they believed she was one of the victims, and claimed the £30,000 they spent for her to be smuggled into Britain had been repaid.

In a press conference this evening, Essex Police Deputy Chief Constable Pippa Mills urged people living in the UK illegally to help them with their investigation.

She added: ‘Please come forward and speak to us without fear. I can assure you that your information will be received in strictest confidence and no criminal action will be taken against you.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

DCC Mills also asked family members to contact the force and tried to reassure them that they would not be in trouble with the police.

A fourth suspect, a man from Northern Ireland, was arrested at Stansted Airport (Picture: PA)

Neighbours said they were ‘shell-shocked’ at the sight of police raiding the Mahers’ home (Picture: PA)

Last night Joanna Maher said they sold the truck to a company in County Monaghan, close to the home of 25-year-old driver Mo Robinson, who was arrested on suspicion of murder on Wednesday and remains in custody.

His name appeared on a draft list for a hearing at Chelmsford Magistrates’ Court tomorrow and another at the city’s crown court on Monday, but the CPS and police say this was a mistake by staff.

Robinson is believed to have driven the tractor unit – the front part – from Northern Ireland over the weekend and collected the container late on Tuesday night.

GPS tracking on the sound-proofed trailer shows it stopping in Dunkirk and Calais in France before heading to Zeebruge, Belgium.

It then made its way to Purfleet, Essex, where the grim discovery was made in the early hours of Wednesday morning.

This evening Essex Police confirmed a fourth suspect is being held over the deaths of 31 men and eight women.

Advertisement

A 48-year-old man from Northern Ireland was arrested at Stansted Airport on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people and murder.

description: Joanna Maher and Thomas Maher, from Warrington, Cheshire, are being held over 39 dead bodies found in a -25C lorry in Essex.
